meta_data.title: Barf Doesn't Belong on the Mount Rushmore of Dog Names, But I Want You to Know I Understood the Reference
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 5:22-23 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey, do you remember like two days ago when we opened an episode of this podcast with a Mount Rushmore exercise? It's pretty fun. Don't get me wrong. I understand why everybody loves them so much. A Mount Rushmore exercise is where I throw out a category and then you blurt out the four things that are most deserving of being listed in that category. So for example, if the category is presidents who should be on Mount Rushmore, you're going to want to yell probably the ones that are on there. I mean, I think that's the obvious answer. So here's one for you. Ready? Top four dog names ever. Which four dog names are on the Mount Rushmore of dog names? What do you got? And some of you right now, you're trying to come up with trendy recent stuff. Don't give me any of that. Give me classic dog names. What'd you come up with? All right. Here's the four I got. Spot, champ, rover, and big number four. Are you with me on this one? What do you have? I'm going Fido. Now in all of these circumstances, I don't know anybody who's had a no. That's not true. That's somebody who owned a Fido. My buddy Eddie had a dog named Fido growing up. And for three of those four, I can see why you wouldn't want to name your dog that. You know, it's not exactly ideal. Champ, it sounds good, but that's going to be a dog from a fancy pedigree. It's going to be real expensive. Rover, that's what one of my two dogs does all the time. And I don't like it. She just roves. If she can get away, she will get away. I don't think that's a positive attribute at all. And then my other dog does what the other name is. Spot, she just spots up on the carpet all over the place. Someday, she's a puppy. Maybe she'll grow out of it. None of those are flattering, but Fido, what does Fido mean? You ever thought about that? They mean faithful, like Fidelles. It's like a, it's just, it's a perfect name for a dog. I mean, it sounds kind of dumb. But I don't think it was a very popular name or anything as I understand it until Abe Lincoln named his dog Fido. And then people suddenly were like, yeah, you know what? Thanks, right. That's exactly what a dog is. Faithful and loyal. That is an ideal name for a dog. So maybe instead of getting all clever next time, I'll just name my dog Fido. Because really, who hates faithfulness, right? Who hates that in a friend? Who hates that in a spouse? Who hates that in a boyfriend or girlfriend? Who hates that in a leader or a mentor? Nobody. We all want faithfulness from the people we put our trust in. And faithfulness, likewise, is one of the attributes of God that is imparted to Christians by the spirit according to Galatians 522. But the fruit of the spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness. Faithfulness, Fido, gentleness, and self-control against such things, there is no law. So what does this faithfulness thing look like? Okay, like pretty much everything else on the list here in the fruit of the spirit, there's kind of an obvious first thing that comes to mind level meaning on that. And then as we start to peel back the layers a little bit biblically, and we discover, hey, this is a more complex idea and there's a lot to it. Well, what is faithfulness at its core? Just as you think of it, before we go and do any Bible stuff, let's just do the exercise together. I don't have this prepared. So I'm workshopping this with you in this exact moment. What is faithfulness? Well it means doing the stuff that you said you were going to do. Let your SBS and your no-be-no, right? People who do that, we consider them faithful. Trusting, but like believing in you, I think that's kind of faithfulness. Maybe that's the perfect terminology that sounded a little bit Disney. But I would say my friends who I call faithful, if something bad was said about me, they would give me the benefit of the doubt. They would have a degree of, well, benefit of the doubt. I think that's the right term. Faithfulness, steady, I think steadiness is something we associate with faithfulness. I think of the faithful people in my life as not really changing. They're not flaky. That is, who they are is who they are. The values they hold are not fluid. They don't change from day to day or circumstance to circumstance. The things that make them them is what they are. Okay, I think that was a pretty fruitful exercise. Maybe you came up with better stuff than I did off the top of my head. But I think I'm in the zip code there. So what do we have when we look for the word faith or faithfulness, specifically faithfulness from stuff around the Bible? I was able to brainstorm a couple. The first one I came up with doesn't, I don't think it even has the word faithfulness in the verse, but it just kind of is a description of faithfulness. Maybe I'm remembering it wrong again. Could have looked all this up in advance. But then we lose the fun vibe of the program, right? Which is we're figuring it out together and we do this every day. So it's not like I have infinite time to solve the whole Bible and then just make a podcast about it and just make the only way for this to work. Practically speaking, it's for us to figure this stuff out together. All right, Psalm 103 17 through 18. There we go. But from everlasting to everlasting, the Lord's love is with those who fear him and his righteousness with their children's children, with those who keep his covenant and remember to obey his precepts. Well, dang, that kind of cuts both ways. There was more there than I remembered. So we're kind of getting into two levels of faithfulness there. The God faithfulness, which is from everlasting to everlasting super steady. He is love back then. He is love now. He will be love later. He's righteous. He's good. Unchanging. The steadiness of God is one level of faithfulness. And the first half of that passage in Psalm 103 focuses on the faithfulness of God, even though it doesn't technically use that exact word. And then the second half, just like all the different things on this list of fruit of the spirit, the second half is kind of us mirroring that. It is humanity touched by God, living life by the spirit, giving those back that, you know, the idea of keeping his covenants and remembering to obey his precepts. The idea is God sets the standard for faithfulness and then faithfulness to whatever degree we can do that by the power of the spirit. That is the response. Let's look at some stuff that actually has faithfulness in the verse. It seems like we need some smoking gun bibling here at this point. Do you all know what I mean? By the way, when I say smoking gun, like, you know, multiple levels of evidence, right? And you picture a one hour detective TV show or whatever, like an old, timey detective show in black and white on TV. And you'd have really contrived solutions some weeks where it was like, well, you were at the market that day when the person with the poisonous powder was there and you would have had time when you slipped behind that dumpster to buy that from them. And you would have had motive because you were over here. That's right. I did it. And in that case, the evidence isn't smoking gun. It's very complex and the clever detective has to piece it together. A lot of stuff that we do in the Bible takes a little cleverness. We got to look at the big picture. We have to consider a lot. Whatever now. And then you come across smoking gun versus, which would be the equivalent of a situation where somebody's going to do something and then, you know, the detective and the good guys run around the corner and there's somebody laying there freshly dead and right in front of them is the bad guy with a gun. Then there's still smoke coming out of the barrel and you just heard a bang and you're like, well, obviously that guy did it because he's holding a gun and the gun is smoking. So some of these verses that we're looking at in this whole fruit of the spirit thing or any kind of work through the Bible together thing are just really overtly right on the nose. There's the thing that's the Bible speaking to this issue. Other stuff is a little more triangulating where we add up a few different things to cobble together a theological point or observation. This one's smoking gun. Proverbs three, three and four, let love and faithfulness never leave you. Send them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart. Then you will win favor and a good name in the sight of God and man. So obviously this one is about faithfulness as an attribute of people. In this case of wise people, the first nine chapters of Proverbs all kind of read like the author of Proverbs is given some coaching to his sons who might turn out to be idiots or maybe by the grace of God they will listen to the metaphorical voice of metaphorical lady wisdom and do things that make sense. And here the exhortation is this idea of faithfulness being steady doing the right thing over the long term internalizing certain virtues and attributes. How do you do that? Well you let love and faithfulness be bound around your neck written on the tablet of your heart. This is similar language to stuff we get in other parts of the Bible about how to internalize God's word or God's law. I think that's very intentional here. And then what happens? Well when you do that, you win favor and a good name and people know you don't flake. They know you show up for things. They know you're reliable. They know that your yes is yes and your no is no. They know that you are steady and my goodness, my parents forced me into such a reputation as a young man. They made me do the things that I said. But if it was up to me, I would have flaked on stuff all the time and squirreled after every single thing that came up next. And I wasn't even born in the digital age. I mean, how hard is it for a kid now to get this right? But the idea of this proverb is that faithfulness isn't just an attribute of God, but it's a very desirable attribute in, well, this is written to young people. The first nine chapters of Proverbs, it's a remarkable attribute when a young person can muster this. And the idea is that love and faithfulness and the law of God, these are things to literally put on your person or metaphorically internalize deeply into your heart so that you become steadily these things. All right, that was a good one. I feel real good about that. Let's do more Old Testament. First Chronicles 1634. I bet some of you right now are like, Hey, I remember that one. I remember as it was on my list of things to memorize. If it wasn't, this is a good one to put on your list. Give thanks to the Lord for he is good. His love endures forever. Now, you might be like, wait, doesn't it kind of more or less say that in other parts of the Bible as well? And the answer is, yeah, that's kind of a famous turn of a phrase there. But the basic point is they give thanks to the Lord. Why is steadiness in this case? This phrase is about praising God for his faithfulness, his consistency, which is a pretty cool thing. So you think about how up and down your emotions are when it comes to your sports team losing a couple of games in a row or terrible forever. They win five in a row work the best thing ever. Your political team scores a couple wins. Everything's going to be great for the future. The other team scores some wins. Oh, this place is going to hell in a hand basket. And we're so up and down. We're so meteoric or mercurial rather. And God isn't. He sees the big picture. His faithfulness is love. They endure forever. He's playing a different game than we're playing. And that is a reason to give thanks to the Lord. Ah, right. What else do we got? Let's stay in the Old Testament. Ooh, do I want to do that one? Nope. Nope. I'm saving this one for tomorrow. I can't believe we're actually doing another two day thing. You remember way back at the beginning of all of this? When I was like, all right, we're going to do the fruit of the spirit. And yeah, it's going to be tempting to do a breakdown of each word. But we're going to try and just, you know, when we pass that, nah, we have not done that at all. We've done at least a day on every single one. And this is going to be a two day on faithfulness plus a little bit more in peace tomorrow. So on average, I think we're going to end up with solidly two for each. And guess what? I don't feel bad. I don't feel bad at all because this is an independent podcast. There is no corporate sponsorship. It is unowned. This is a guy in his shed talking about the Bible and processing it through in real time with you, which means that it goes where it goes. And where it goes right now is apparently super deep dive into a wide biblical view of all the fruit of the spirit. And I'm having a blast. This has been really fun, especially as kind of a reward here at the end of a somewhat contentious book. I mean, Galatians, it's argumentative. It's important arguments get why it's contentious. It had to be. But this is a nice and really pleasant reward. It's nice. I'm enjoying it. So hey, what do you know? Two days on faithfulness. I got more tomorrow. I'm going to turn off this microphone and go see if my rover is roving or if my spot is spotting. Good chance one or the other is doing one of those two things. Should have named him Fido. I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
